subject: RE: [junit] Parameterized test case pattern + a suggestion for improving the Cookbook
msgSnippet: Eugene, I recently wrote a tester that dynamically created tests and I was very glad I knew to override runTest(). That way I could store useful information in
messageBody:
Eugene,

I recently wrote a tester that dynamically created tests and I was very glad
I knew to override runTest(). That way I could store useful information in
the name and have the tests print meaningfully in the test runner. I think
using the name as a pluggable selector is a little ugly, but justified given
how much it simplifies test writing.

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute

> -----Original Message-----
> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Eugene Kuleshov
> Sent: Monday, November 21, 2005 8:32 AM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: Re: [junit] Parameterized test case pattern + a
> suggestion for improving the Cookbook
>
> I do believe that overriding runTest() is a really ugly hack. It is
> really enough to override getName() method to make suite tests look
> different.
